content.description: Start off a juniper branch right against the wall to a few good pockets. The crux comes fast with a huge right hand deadpoint off of some small holds. 3rd bolt to the top is probably 5.10 and is really fun.
content.location: Basically starts in between the two junipers along the wall before "Dinosaur Rock"

content.description: The large, white, left facing corner is a good crag organizer.
content.location: The right margin of the opening, West sector, is the obvious tall, white, left facing corner. A bit of an overhang getting into the botton of the dihederal, then casual stemming with pockets and grimps.

content.description: This verticle seam, Western Family, marks the left margin of the marquis central Sector. Wicked series of micro deadpoints at bolt 4 and finally into decent pockets as the crack dissapears into black colored dolostone.
content.location: Left margin of marquis sector. Left of Little Perdro's Mexican Tidal Wave and the not recorded here yet, Sufer Rosa 5.12d slab.

content.description: Hard slab moves lead to slopey pockets to the 3rd bolt or so, then it eases up towards the top. Hardly ever gets done and is pretty sharp. Not a bad route, but not worth your time at Baldwin.
Savage little number, with complicated movement into gaston dynamics. At least the upper section is straight forward 5.12 pocket climbing.
Next to the lone shade tree (left of it). Starts on underclings. Sequential moves trend right to easier rock above.

Do the first couple moves on the great pockets of Mask Without a Face, then moving up and left into a powerful boulder problem beginning with an undercling, a spock-pocket, then a desperate toss to a good jug and an ok shake.  from here a thin and sequential but slightly easier boulder problem at the top of the bulge guards the slab above.  Great rock and similar to Mask, but with much harder movement.
content.protection: 4 bolts to rings.  1st bolt and anchors shared with Mask
content.location: Left of Mask Without a Face, middle route of three on the steep, short, and heavily pocketed wall.

content.description: Once, the most popular tick in this sector. Tres Amigos has a crux in the low panel, tossing for the white heuco. But more notably the entire top section is on sustained but incut and straight forward, crisp, pumpy but keeper pockets!
Just right of Cowboy This on the main wall.  This route would be 12c and six stars if not for a ridiculous crimp move in the crux.
Far right side of the cliff.  To the left of Orange for Anguish.  Sustained climbing up a steep wall.

Orange streak, center of marquis section of Baldwin Creek Canyon.

A classic. Steep, pocketed, pure. Singles at the crux.

Juan !$
content.location: Orange streak, center of marquis section of Baldwin Creek Canyon.

content.description: Go up an arete/corner for 2 bolts, then bust right out a wild rail on the lip of the roof. Hard crux as soon as you get your feet under you. go up on cool pockets and continuing steepness.
content.location: To the left of the rotting break in the cliff, and the shorty route, sideshow bob.

content.description: Right of Bravery.  Good pockets and (you guessed it) a hard sequence over the small roof.
Steep climbing on perfect stone.  5.13 to an okay shake and then very hard bouldering up high.
content.location: Far right (down canyon) end of Baldwin crag.

content.description: Left side of wall.  Shares start with a 13a to its left and climbs up steep rock on good pockets.  Long move/dead point crux.
Climb perfect rock up the blue steak, hard vert-slab climbing.
content.location: The line follows the unmistakable blue streak on the vert wall to the right of the arching roof and white slab a la piston hurricane, bravery, and amused to death.

content.description: Start a couple meters left of Brave Cowboy initial corner. Two routes start here; Barbarosa by Frank is the right variation, Little Pedro's Mexican Tidal Wave is the left one. A Steep headwall with big, but flat holds.
Main wall a few routes right of Brave Cowboy.  Follows a seam up overhanging rock.  Sustained.
Thin climbing leads to an undercling, a couple pulls over a small roof, and a fun, pockety headwall.
content.location: Right of Voodoo Chile and Losing Streak, and left of Withering heights and a big juniper.

content.description: Climb alternating bulge and slab on sustained moves using a variety of pockets.  Good if a 5.10 warm up is needed.
content.location:
isolated, 20 feet right of One Trick Pony, starts on a grassy ledge.

Peregrine Falcons have been known to nest in this section of the cliff.  If you see them, leave promptly and give them some space.

climbs.name: The Bravery of Being Out of Range

content.description: Second route right of the shade tree. Bravery goes through the highest part of a small roof.  It has a stinger crux on shallow 2 finger pockets to get over this roof with a ridiculously high left foot.
Main wall.  Starts to the right of Supple Cowboy and trends left toward that route.  Very hard bolder problem at 2/3 height.

Perhaps the best 5.12a in the Lander area. This route begins on the left side of the main wall at Baldwin. Start up an incipent crack that peters out as the wall steepens. Expect small pockets and crimpers. The crux is around mid height with a "six pack" undercling mono/thumb hold for the left hand. Pumpy and sustained.

Start in a mono and undercling your way up and over a small roof and into a small corner.  Exit the corner on wierd moves, and enter a just-over-vert headwall with mostly good pockets.  This goes on for 5-ish clips.  The bottom is only worth doing for the top.
content.location: second route right of the huge black break and low cave

content.description: Just right of the shade tree.  Climbs up the small roof shared with Bravery.  Crux at the lip, then easier but run out climbing above.
Mono crux low and double mono crux high. "At least u rest the rest of your fingers"
content.location: left of "Festus" right of "Cowboy This" itâ€™s on the mini black wave, right of Marquis Central Sector, left of shade tree.
